frameDefinitions: The words in this frame describe an Experiencer's emotions with respect to some Content.
In this frame either a Stimulus brings about a particular emotion or experience in the Experiencer or  saliently fails to bring about a particular experience.
These words refer to an Agent joining Parts to form a Whole.
A Stimulus serves to bring about an emotion of mental stimulation in an Experiencer.
The adjectives and nouns in this frame describe an Experiencer who is feeling or experiencing a particular emotional response to a Stimulus or about a Topic.
The words in this frame refer to facial Expressions and the Possessors of those Expressions.
frameExamples: My <t>enjoyment</t> of the movie was considerably impaired by the seven-foot guy sitting in front of me.
You will not easily find a more <t>absorbing</t> box-set of piano discs.
Mr. Whiskers is <t>upset</t> that there are no more cat treats.
listRoleDefinitions: The <fen>Experiencer</fen> experiences the emotion or other internal state.

<fen>Content</fen> is what the <fen>Experiencer</fen>'s feelings or experiences are directed towards or based upon.  The <fen>Content</fen> differs from a stimulus because the <fen>Content</fen> is not construed as being direcly responsible for causing the emotion.

The Frame Element <fen>Expressor</fen> marks expressions that indicate a body part, gesture or other expression of the <fen>Experiencer</fen> that reflect his or her emotional state.  They describe a presentation of the experience or emotion denoted by the adjective or noun.
The <fen>Topic</fen> is the area about which the <fen>Experiencer</fen> has the particular experience.
The <fen>State</fen> is the abstract noun that describes a more lasting experience by the <fen>Experiencer</fen>.
The <fen>Event</fen> is the occasion or happening that <fen>Experiencer</fen>s in a certain emotional state participate in.
The time at which the <fen>Experiencer</fen> is in the specified emotional state.
The <fen>Stimulus</fen> is the object or event which brings about the emotion in the <fen>Experiencer</fen>.

In causative uses of these verbs there is an <fen>Agent</fen> responsible for amalgamating the <fen>Parts</fen>. The <fen>Agent</fen> is generally the External Argument (or the object of a PP-by in passives).
This  role identifies <fen>Whole</fen> as the entity resulting from combination of <fen>Parts</fen>.  When overtly expressed, it is usually a PP Complement (often headed by into).
This role identifies the <fen>Parts</fen> entities being combined, and is often expressed in a single plural NP, usually the direct object of a verb.
This role identifies the first of two <fen>Parts</fen> mentioned. It  is most often the NP-Object of a verb.
This role identifies the second of two <fen>Parts</fen> mentioned. It is usually a PP Complement.
The time at which the amalgamation occurs.
The location that the event occurs.
The <fen>Experiencer</fen> is the person or sentient entity that experiences or feels the emotions.
The <fen>Stimulus</fen> is the person, event, or state of affairs that evokes the emotional response in the <fen>Experiencer</fen>.
The <fen>Time</fen> when the <fen>Experiencer</fen>  can be described as having said emotion.
The <fen>Experiencer</fen> is the person or sentient entity that experiences or feels the emotions.
The <fen>Topic</fen> is the general area in which the emotion occurs.  It indicates a range of possible <fen>Stimulus</fen>.
The <fen>Stimulus</fen> is the person, event, or state of affairs that evokes the emotional response in the <fen>Experiencer</fen>.

The Frame Element <fen>Expressor</fen> marks expressions that indicate a body part, gesture or other expression of the <fen>Experiencer</fen> that reflects his or her emotional state.  They describe a presentation of the experience or emotion denoted by the adjective or noun.
The <fen>State</fen> is the abstract noun that describes a more lasting experience by the <fen>Experiencer</fen>.
The <fen>Event</fen> is the occasion or happening that <fen>Experiencer</fen>s in a certain emotional state participate in.
This is the <fen>Expression</fen> made.
This is the person who exhibitis the <fen>Expression</fen>.
The emotion that is conveyed by a particular <fen>Expression</fen>.
listRoleExamples: Everyone loves <fex>compliments</fex>.
The delight <fex>on her face</fex> was mixed with asonishment.
Mr. Whiskers was upset <fex>about his cat treats</fex>.
Tracy was in an irritated <fex>mood</fex>.
It felt pretty awkward to partake in such a nervous <fex>ceremony</fex>.
<fex>Last year</fex>, Bob was still interested in the young Republicans.
<fex>The chef</fex> combined the ingredients.
Chuck merged the corpora <fex>into a database</fex>.
Chuck merged <fex>the corpora</fex> into a database.
The workmen joined <fex>the annex</fex> to the main building.
The workkmen joined the annex <fex>to the main building</fex>.
Nan Ho turned, <fex>his</fex> extreme agitation unnoticed by the Prince.
I was angry <fex>about the war</fex>.
Liz's anger <fex>towards Raquel</fex> dates back to a charity dinner this year.
'Can I help you?' she asked, trying not to let him see the amusement <fex>in her blue eyes</fex>.
Tracy was in an irritated <fex>mood</fex>.
The end of the film was filled with jubilant <fex>scenes</fex>.
He gave a wide <fex>grin</fex>.
<fex>Ryan</fex> grinned.
He had an <fex>angry</fex> expression.
